author: gilvania
title: Cardano for STEM Brazilian students
description: There is a lack of courses on blockchain in Brazilian Universities leaving our students out of these technological advances. Most educational contents are in English, but Brazilians speak Portuguese.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal plans on creating a new course on blockchain and cardano to the students of the college of  Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics, university of Pernambuco. And this in Portuguese, which the native language of those targeted potential participants (students). The learning from this course will be an addition to the knowledge of students, and they can apply this technology to improve fields such as cryptocurrency, supply chain, data management, healthcare, governance, and others.
This demonstrates that the proposal is impactful and aligned with the challenge objectives, since after taking the courses, some students may decide to get involved into the catalyst and cardano ecosystem and apply for funding for some related projects.
I would rate this with a 5 star.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer is a doctor in Physics and an associate professor at a Brazilian Engineering College (Pernambuco University), with experience in condensed matter physics, computing, and data analysis, which shows she understand the basics around the blockchain, but she hasn't had previously any work in and around the catalyst project. This may be a challenge for her as she'll have to learn and get familiar with the catalyst process.. 
The budget breakdown covers main project expenses, but amounts allocated to the  Books expenses (USD 250); Marketing (USD 200); Websites (USD 100); Services (USD 250) seems low, especially since the projection is to make Pernambuco university becomes a pioneer hub on courses in Portuguese around cardano and the blockchain in Brazil. Increase these amounts in a perspective of sustaining the availability of the course, and why not diversify the types of courses, exploring various topics within the cardano blockchain.
The proposer would have thought of adding few more people to her team, to decrease  the workload, but also increase collaboration. Catalyst philosophy being also based on 
team work.
Work experience and expertise of the proposer would help the team to make this proposal a success, and as it's presented, the project is feasible, except elements I raised above.
f6_assessments.q2:
being a continuation of a proposal funded in fundd-7 (https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/381790) would help the community to continue following the implementation, but the proposer doesn't detail how will this ne done, by  which mechanism.
Also, for indicators of success I would mention the number of students registered to the course, which wasn't mentioned.
I would rate this with a 4 star.

f6_assessments.q0:
For the next generation of Science, Engineering, Technology, and Mathematics (STEM) students, understanding blockchain technology is essential because they can use it to advance industries like cryptocurrencies, supply chains, data management, healthcare, governance, and more. Nevertheless, there aren't many courses on this crucial subject offered in our Brazilian educational institutions. The majority of students who are interested in learning about this technology must be fluent in English and take international online courses on it.
The purpose of this proposal is to offer free, Portuguese-language courses about Blockchain and Cardano from a scientific standpoint to engineering and natural science students.
At a university in Brazil, a basic course on blockchain technology and Cardano will be offered. There will be a total of 10 hours of instruction split between in-person sessions at the University of Pernambuco in Brazil and online sessions on the platform Zoom.
The challenge's objectives specifically call for this. The proposer has also listed the crucial criteria that are crucial to the success of this proposal. The proposer has already mentioned the challenges they will experience, and they are scalable and offer alternate answers.

f6_assessments.q0:
I think the proposal is suitable for this challenge setting, and the contribution it makes is decent. As for context, this proposal is a continuation of the same idea from Fund 7. One of the problems right now is that students, even from IT backgrounds, don’t get a formal education on what blockchain is. This is critical because the students are the ones who will drive technology development in the future, so equipping them with blockchain materials would help them use it to solve current problems that might exist. What I like best about this proposal is that the syllabus is very basic, which helps students understand what kind of usecases the blockchain would allow, why it exists in the first place, and why it is designed the way it is. Therefore, after the course, the students are more versed when discussing how blockchain could revolutionize the world. I appreciate that the proposer put Cardano specifically in the syllabus.

That being said, I do wonder if there are any changes compared to the previous implementation. Maybe there are certain topics that need more time, or maybe new topics that need to be added to the syllabus. I would very much want to hear the proposer’s opinion about what’s lacking in the previous lectures or what could be improved in general. It's a missed opportunity to not supplement the proposal with reflective tweaks, but in the end, I still agree with its contribution.
f6_assessments.q1:
I tend to agree that the proposal could be implemented successfully, mainly because the proposer has done it in Fund 7. I watched one of the recordings from the courses and the lecturer used Cardano's official documentation and Charles' whiteboard video as the main sources, which shows that they refer to reliable sources. There is no problem with the timetable as it is the same as with previous lectures. Overall, based on the Fund 7 implementation, there seems to be no major hindrance that might occur.

However, I would like the proposer to break down the budget a bit more precisely. The budget allocated for book expenses, websites, and services should have an explanation to justify them. For example, why does the proposer need to buy books (can’t they just use online resources)? Which books are they buying? Why is there a budget allocated for a website when the previous lectures used Zoom? What services do they mean exactly? Why is the professor's payment 4200 USD? How many professors do they provide? How many hours are spent on lecturing? These are some guiding questions that might help the proposer better justify their budget request.
f6_assessments.q2: With current information given to us, it is unclear how we could audit their entire process or results. The milestones provided are sufficient, and we could kind of imagine what the overarching timeline would be. The metrics the proposer used are the students' feedback, the number of views, and the number of questions. I find these metrics to be reasonable enough, but we can’t really publicly access this information. One way to mitigate this is perhaps by creating a publicly available, shareable Google Drive, in which the proposer would upload the aforementioned numbers. It also allows the proposer to upload in-person class notes and Zoom recordings to the same place. As of now, there isn’t really a way to see any updates regarding the classes.

f6_assessments.q0:
The fundamental motivation behind the "Challenge & Scouted for Students" Challenge approved by the Catalyst community last fund, is to provide college and university students a space completely separate from the regular Catalyst funding environment, in which they could bring their projects to our ecosystem and get base funding, nothing financially ambitious.  Clumsy projects, with flaws or weaknesses if any, but with an authentic innovative and creative student spirit, insolent and daring, that could find in our community a place to learn and get involved, a playground endowed not only with money, but even more valuable, with the possibility to get your hands on the best technology in the industry while having access to the knowledge, experience and sense of collaboration of Catalyst members. A new concept for Catalyst no doubt, but an efficient one: in the student community of the planet lies that needle in the haystack that ends up changing the game we play so tightly with other blockchains and the legacy world, and it is our obligation to build the best of the magnets to find it.  That's exactly what this Challenge is trying to do: build a suitable habitat for students.

Because of my affinity with this Challenge (formal experience in education at the college, university, corporate level) and my experience in Project Catalyst (actively participating in 90% of the community positions that exist: CA, VCA, Challenge Team member, funded proposer, involvement in multiple projects in Catalyst) I have been following it closely since it was approved at F8, because it never ceases to amaze me how often the scoreboard seeks to augment itself with topics of undeniable importance (Developer Ecosystem, Cross-Chain Collaboration, The Great Migration (From Ethereum)) to the point of discarding areas that in the real world have proven to be an inexhaustible source of ideas, creativity and results, such as those related to students.  

As an educator and Catalyst member, I understand the intent behind the proposal and consider it completely valid.  However, the proposal is designed FOR students but not BY students. And that is a fundamental requirement of the Challenge.  I quote (excerpted from the Challenge information) "By creating a category of students and increasing exposure for their ideas, they can expect easier funding and to be scouted by engineers" (section What does success look like?). "Most student entrepreneurs suffer from a shortage of resources, especially when it comes to funding and hiring engineers" (Why is this important? section). "However, the number of proposals to Catalysts is increasing rapidly, and the community does not readily perceive small-scale proposals from students. .... Therefore, to make it easier for the community to recognize new ideas from students, we will establish a new category exclusively for students" (Challenge brief section).  

In conclusion, to maintain the spirit of the Challenge “Challenge & Scouted for Students” I have to remove three stars from the final score.
f6_assessments.q1: In my experience as an educator, the implementation plan and budget correspond to the line of work the proposer wishes to execute.  The proposer's track record is astounding, a compendium of knowledge, experience and accomplishments that any student in practice could wish for.  And it is precisely there where the weakness of the proposal lies: it is competing in a category whose guidelines it is not respecting.  As evidenced in the Impact section of this evaluation, the Challenge guidelines are clearly stated with respect to the profile eligible to submit proposals.  Therefore, I must remove three stars from the final rating.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs provided by the proposal can accomplish the performance measurement tasks required.  In general, the project presents a feasible and measurable scenario.  However, proceeding to measure its performance would mean measuring the performance of a project that is outside the guidelines that were clearly given to the Challenge “Challenge & Scouted for Students”  competitors.  Therefore, similar to trying to break a physical law, I see measuring the project as impossible.  Consequently, I must remove 4 stars from the final rating.

f6_assessments.q2:
In Brazil, it is common for Educational Institutions to use the Moodle Platform to offer courses for their students. Each institution has its own platform, and for one to have access to the classes, it is required a registration with a CPF number. This number is unique, and all Brazilian citizens and legal foreigns have it.  The course mentioned in the project, is lectured inside this platform and a lot of the community members would not be able to audit it, since they do not have this CPF number. Considering this, I would recommend either creating a open platform (such as a YouTube channel) or, specifically for this course, make the registration easier (non-compulsory CPF number) or lectured in another platform.   
Although what was said above limits the auditability of the project, I think the roadmap was well prepared with clear milestones. However, the KPI's do not go in the same direction of what was proposed by the challenge.
